text: alcohol in the immortal words of Homer

the active ingredient in almost all

whether it's a shot of spirits whether
it's half a pint of beer inside there is
about 10 milliliters of ethanol in the
UK we call that one unit of alcohol it's
the amount of ethanol and alcohol that
an adult can process in one hour and
even a 125 milliliter glass of wine has
around about one and a half units in it
men are recommended to drink between 3 &
4 units maximum a day and for women
that's around about 2 to 3 okay so it's
the ethanol that's getting you drunk but
how does it actually get into your
system well when I take a sip of beer
the ethanol is absorbed through the
lining of my mouth it turns out you can

American Fraternity phenomenon of butt

it is so much easier to overdose from

place now once my drink has gone down
the right way about 20 percent of the

more likely Prosecco it goes right to my
head once it hits your bloodstream
alcohol
starts messing with your brain it
enhances the effect of a
neurotransmitter called GABA
gamma-aminobutyric acid now what that
normally does is it inhibits nerves from
sending messages so if alcohol enhances
the effect of gaba les messages are sent
by those nerves and you are slow to
respond and you start feeling a little
bit woozy alcohol also messes with your
central nervous system leaving you
uncoordinated and it slows down your
breathing rate your heart rate and your
brain function now all that sounds
rather miserable what about the more
positive effects you often see is people
get more and more tipsy well alcohol
also affects your central cortex making
you feel less inhibited and more free
and more like it would be a really good
idea to go and have a go some karaoke
the thing is though despite alcohol
being one of the world's most popular
drugs scientists still can't agree on
what the positive reinforcement must be
that makes us want to keep on drinking
and they even argue on whether Pleasant
effects come from something it must be
from the metabolic breakdown of the
alcohol not the stuff itself time for
the big question though why does alcohol
make you pee so much
well you normally rely on vasopressin
and antidiuretic hormone to control your
peeing frequency but alcohol stops you
making vasopressin hence your pee more
and all that pain may explain why you

so what could explain that terrible

may be the hangover like the alcohols

one in three men and one in six women
